3.text: Pick a neutral, food-grade oil with which to season your cookware.

4.text: Warm your cast iron cookware up a little bit, if you wish.

5.text: Apply a thin layer of oil or shortening onto your cast iron cookware.

6.text: Use a clean cloth or paper towel to wipe off extra oil or shortening.

7.text: Choose between oven or stove curing.

8.text: Use aluminum foil to protect your oven.

9.text: Place your cast iron cookware into your oven.

10.text: Allow the cookware to heat for about half an hour.

11.text: Turn the oven off and allow the cookware to cool.

12.text: Take the cookware out of oven and remove any excess oil or shortening that may have presented during the initial heating.

13.text: Put the cookware back into the oven, except this time, put it in upside down.

14.text: Reheat the cookware for at least 1 hour.

15.text: Let the cookware cool down to room temperature before removing it again.

16.text: Consider repeating the seasoning process a few more times.

17.text: Cover the cookware with a lid.

18.text: Place the cookware on a matching-size element on the stove.

19.text: Every 5-15 minutes check for a light hazy smoke under the cover.

20.text: When increasing the heat slightly ceases to make the pan smoke, remove the pan from heat but leave the heat on.

21.text: After the pan has cooled, apply another thin coat, cover, and let sit for an hour at the ideal temperature you found.

22.text: Finally (and from now on after every time you cook), scrub it out with a plastic brush and regular table salt.
